title: 107_s2067
content: The Medicare Safety Net Access Act of 2002, also known as the "Medicare Safety Net Access Act," includes provisions for supplemental reimbursement for Federally qualified health centers participating in Medicare managed care. It also revises payment limits for these health centers, expands coverage of additional services, and provides safe harbor for collaborative efforts benefiting medically underserved populations. The Medicare Safety Net Access Act of 2002 amends Section 1833(a)(3) of the Social Security Act to provide supplemental reimbursement for services described in section 1832(a)(2)(D), with payment not exceeding 80 percent of reasonable costs. The Medicare Safety Net Access Act of 2002 amends Section 1833(a)(3) of the Social Security Act to provide supplemental reimbursement for services described in section 1832(a)(2)(D), with payment not exceeding 80 percent of reasonable costs. In certain cases, the payment may exceed 80 percent under specific conditions outlined in the legislation. The Medicare Safety Net Access Act of 2002 provides special payment rules for Federally Qualified Health Center services under Medicare+Choice, excluding financial incentives like risk pool payments, bonuses, or withholds. The Medicare Safety Net Access Act of 2002 outlines payment rules for Federally Qualified Health Centers under Medicare+Choice, ensuring direct payments to the centers without reducing monthly payments to Medicare+Choice organizations. Amendments are made to sections of the Social Security Act to accommodate these payment arrangements. Amendments are made to Section 1857(e) of the Social Security Act to require Medicare+Choice organizations to enter into agreements with Federally Qualified Health Centers for equal access to services. Amendments to Section 1857(e) of the Social Security Act require Medicare+Choice organizations to ensure equal payment levels to Federally Qualified Health Centers for services provided under written agreements. Amendments to Section 1857(e) of the Social Security Act mandate that Federally Qualified Health Centers must accept the Medicare+Choice contract price plus the Federal payment as payment in full for services covered by the contract, with the exception of permissible cost-sharing amounts. Amendments to the Social Security Act provide a safe harbor from the antikickback prohibition for remuneration between Federally Qualified Health Centers and Medicare+Choice organizations. The amendments made by this section apply to services provided on or after January 1, 2003, and contract years beginning on or after that date. SEC. 3 revises payment limits for Federally Qualified Health Centers, allowing for adjustments in per visit payment amounts for specific services. The effective date for this amendment is January 1, 2003. SEC. 4 expands coverage for additional services provided by Federally Qualified Health Centers. The amendment expands coverage for Federally Qualified Health Center services to include preventive primary health services required under section 330 of the Public Health Service Act when furnished to an individual as a patient of a Federally qualified health center. PROVIDING SAFE HARBOR FOR CERTAIN COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS BENEFITING MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS. In General, an amendment is made to Section 1128B(b)(3) of the Social Security Act to include remuneration between a public or nonprofit private health center entity and individuals/entities providing goods or services that produce a community benefit. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish standards for the exception for health center entity arrangements to the antikickback penalties, focusing on maintaining or enhancing services for medically underserved populations.
